item.title: Snowfall paints Kashmir white - Greater Kashmir

item.title: 'No One Should Blame Girl For Being With Male Friend': Madras HC Orally Remarks In Plea For CBI Probe... - Live Law - Indian Legal News
item.description:
Madras High Court Emphasizes Victim's Rights in Anna University Sexual Assault Case

Date: December 27, 2024

Source: Live Law

The Madras High Court heard pleas for a CBI probe into the sexual assault of a student at Anna University, stressing that victims should not be blamed for the circumstances surrounding their assault.

  • The court clarified that no one should blame the victim for being with her boyfriend during the incident.
  • It criticized the State Government for leaking the FIR and emphasized the need for privacy and respect for victims.
  • The court raised concerns about campus security, pointing out that many surveillance cameras were non-functional at the time of the incident.
  • There were questions regarding the legality of the police commissioner’s remarks about the investigation status.
  • The case has significant implications regarding the accountability of law enforcement and university authorities.
“Just because this incident has happened, no one should blame the girl for sitting with her boyfriend. It is her private right.”

The court's remarks reflect a growing awareness of victim rights and the importance of privacy in legal proceedings, while also demanding higher accountability from law enforcement and educational institutions.

item.title: Delhi pollution: CAQM revokes GRAP 3 measures as rain improves air quality - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Delhi Pollution: CAQM Revokes GRAP 3 Measures as Rain Improves Air Quality

Date: Dec 27, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

Delhi's air pollution levels showed a declining trend, prompting the Centre's anti-pollution panel to revoke Stage 3 curbs under the Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP) due to improved air quality brought on by rain.

  • The 24-hour average air quality index (AQI) was 324 at 7 PM.
  • CAQM stated that air quality shifted from 'severe' to 'poor', allowing the withdrawal of Stage 3 measures.
  • Stage 1 and 2 measures will remain in effect to prevent further deterioration.
  • The significant impact of rain is expected to continue improving air quality in the city.
  • GRAP Stage 3 included bans on non-essential construction, hybrid schooling for younger students, and restrictions on certain vehicles.
"Delhi's air quality has shifted from the 'severe' category to the 'poor' range. As a result, measures under Stage III, implemented earlier, are now being withdrawn." - CAQM

In conclusion, the recent rainfall in Delhi has led to a notable improvement in air quality, prompting authorities to ease certain pollution control measures while maintaining vigilance to ensure continued air quality management.

item.description:
China Defends the Construction of the World's Largest Dam Over the Brahmaputra River

Date: Dec 27, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

The Chinese foreign ministry announced plans for a $137 billion dam on the Brahmaputra River in Tibet, asserting that it will not adversely affect neighboring countries along the river.

  • The dam is part of a major infrastructure project in the ecologically sensitive Himalayan region.
  • China claims it has conducted extensive studies to ensure the project's safety and environmental impact.
  • Work on the dam aims to foster international cooperation on disaster prevention and relief.
  • Construction will take at least a decade and will connect to the grid further east.
  • Concerns have been raised about potential water flow reductions affecting downstream countries, especially India.
“Everybody downstream is going to be concerned about what it means if water flow is reduced. I know India is very anxious about it.” - David Fishman, energy consulting firm

This ambitious project highlights the complexities of managing international rivers and the geopolitical implications for neighboring nations.

item.title: Madras High Court slams TN Police for leaking FIR copy of Anna University sexual assault - Bar & Bench - Indian Legal News
item.description:
Madras High Court Criticizes Police for FIR Leak in Anna University Assault Case

Published on: 27 Dec 2024, 12:59 pm

The Madras High Court has condemned the Chennai Police for leaking the identity of a 19-year-old student who was assaulted at Anna University, questioning the implications for the victim's family and the broader chilling effect on victims coming forward.

  • The Court expressed concern over the police's failure to redact the victim's identity in the FIR.
  • Justice SM Subramaniam emphasized that the negligence could deter future victims from approaching law enforcement.
  • The incident involved the arrest of a biryani vendor accused of sexually assaulting the student on December 23.
  • The Court is demanding answers from the police regarding lapses and the portrayal of the investigation's status.
  • Concerns were raised over the operational capacity of CCTV cameras at the university during the incident.
“You can upload the FIR but you are supposed to redact identity details. The damage caused to the victim and her family can't be taken back by you.”

The Court's remarks reflect a critical stance towards systemic issues in handling sexual assault cases, emphasizing the need for accountability and protective measures for victims.
